awd_titl_txt: A combined theory-experiment study of electronic, magnetic and thermal properties of complex oxide nano-structures
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Transition metal ceramics exhibit a wide range of properties and functionalities, making them the ideal materials for many next generation electronic devices and sensors. However, the response of many transition metal ceramics to external stimuli, such as heat or electro-magnetic fields remains unknown. This is especially true when the size of device structures is approaching the nanometer scale and the response of the material differs from that observed in the bulk. In this project, a novel approach is explored for measuring, at the nanometer scale, the response of transition metal ceramics to changes in temperature or applied electric or magnetic fields. The combined experimental/theoretical approach is then used to quantify and control the magnetic, electronic and thermal transport properties at interfaces in nanoscale transition metal ceramic materials. The project's research activities center around education and training of science and engineering undergraduate and graduate students. Recruitment and training focuses on the next generation of researchers, in particular involving students from underrepresented groups and minorities through the National Name Exchange program and partnership with local high schools. The participation of undergraduate students in active research projects is fostered through the PI's Journal of Undergraduate Research at the University of Illinois at Chicago. Graduates typically find employment in academia, National Laboratories or industry, including semiconductor companies. 

TECHNICAL DETAILS: The objectives of this research project are to develop a fundamental understanding of the atomic-scale mechanisms that govern the electronic, magnetic and thermal properties of transition metal perovskite oxide hetero-structures. Two transition ceramic systems are studied, one exhibiting novel magnetic and transport properties below a specific film thickness and the other showing ferroelectric properties and the potential existence of a 2-dimensional electron gas. A combination of in-situ scanning transmission electron microscopy and first-principles density functional theory (DFT) calculations is used together with thin-film and nano-particle synthesis. The project consists of two tasks: 1) Utilizing a novel approach towards measuring the thermal expansion coefficient with nanometer resolution and exploring whether this approach can be utilized to quantify the thermal expansion and transport across substrate/film interfaces. This approach is based on measuring the plasmon peak shift as a function of temperature combined with ab-initio modeling of the materials' dielectric response. 2) Understanding the magnetic and electric transport properties of perovskite oxide thin films. The transport anomalies in ultra-thin cobalt-oxide epitaxial films are examined and compared to films grown on different substrates. The effects of interfacial charges on the electronic structure and ferroelectric polarization of Ti-oxides on compound semiconductor substrates are examined. The integration of research and education through the training of undergraduate and graduate students in state-of-the-art in-situ scanning transmission electron microscopy and theoretical materials physics is an integral feature of this project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Summary: Transition metal ceramics exhibit a wide range of properties and functionalities, making them the ideal materials for many next generation electronic devices and sensors. However, the response of many transition metal ceramics to external stimuli, such as heat or electro-magnetic fields remains unknown. This is especially true when the size of device structures is approaching the nanometer scale and the response of the material can be different from that observed in the bulk. In this project, the PI focused on combining in-situ scanning transmission electron microscopy and materials modeling to develop an atomic-scale understanding of how materials behave under various forms of external stimuli.

Intellectual Merit: In this combined experimental/theoretical proposal, a fundamental understanding of the atomic-scale mechanisms that govern the electronic, magnetic, and thermal properties of transition metal ceramics was explored. Using atomic0resoution imaging, low-loss EELS and first principles density functional theory modeling three different thrusts were pursued. First, the thermal expansion coefficient of various oxide and low dimensional materials, such as MXenes, was determined with nano-meter resolution. The effects of temperature induced phase transitions, structural or electronic, on the plasmon resonance and the thermal expansion coefficient were measured. It was found that phase transitions in materials, such as BaTiO3, can now be directly determined using the shift of the plasmon peak as a function of temperature.

The second thrust focused on utilizing machine learning (ML) for automated anomaly detection in electron microscopy images. The PIs developed a new approach for anomaly detection in STEM images of ceramics, such as SrTiO3, using a convolution neural network approach. Working with a UIC undergraduate student, the PI discovered that a neural network trained only on perfect bulk data is capable of detecting and distinguishing several types of defects in SrTiO3. This approach is fully transferrable to other structures and can be performed in real-time.

Finally, in a thirst thrust, the PI began a collaboration with a group at the University of Chicago to explore novel approaches to synthesizing and functionalizing MXenes structure. Various approaches of MXenes synthesis were pursued and it was reported the MXenes with single elemental termination can be synthesized and exfoliated to form monolayer structures. Moir? superlattice were also discovered.

Broader Impacts: The PIs have jointly supervised 5 undergraduate students and 3 graduate students. Two graduate student supported by this program, Xue Rui and Francisco Lagunas, have successfully defended her thesis in 2019 and 2023, respectively. Francisco Lagunas also won numerous national awards, such as the Microscopy Society of America Graduate Student Award, as well as the UIC Access to Excellence Fellowship. In addition, the PI has established a visiting student program with Tecnologico de Monterrey in Mexico. In the Spring and Fall 2022, three female undergraduate students spend 4 months of their senior year in the PI?s group, learning about state-of-the-art transmission electron microscopy. Overall, 10 publications have been published,  with three papers having been selected as cover art in the journal Science, the Journal of the American Chemical Society and the journal Small. In 2021, the PI Klie was also elected as a Fellow of the Microscopy Society of America, in part due to his work supported by this NSF Ceramics grant. In late 2022, MRS TV produced a 5-minute video of the PI?s research supported by this NSF grant. The video was shown at the 2022 MRS Fall Meeting and on YouTube.
